thread.title: Video shows Wellington taxi's intersection dash | Stuff.co.nz
thread.title_full: Video shows Wellington taxi's intersection dash | Stuff.co.nz

author: Tom Hunt
title: Video shows Wellington taxi's intersection dash | Stuff.co.nz
text:
Video shows Wellington taxi's intersection dash TOM HUNT Last updated 10:30, February 23 2017 Chris Orsman 
Chris Orsman caught a Wellington taxi driver swerving around a stopped car on a dangerous dash through a red light. 
A Wellington taxi driver has been caught on camera swerving around a parked car, into an oncoming lane, and running a red light during rush-hour. 
Chris Orsman caught the startling video on his dashcam on Tinakori Rd, Wellington, during rush hour at 5.50pm on Wednesday. 
The Kiwi Cabs taxi, heading north on Tinakori Rd, can be seen approaching the right-turning lane to get on to the Wellington Motorway. Supplied 
A Kiwi Cabs driver, in white car at back, swerves around a car stopped for an orange light to make a dash through a Tinakori Rd intersection. 
Kiwi Cabs confirmed the driver would be fired as this incident followed another complaint about him just two weeks before. 
READ MORE: Supplied 
Oncoming cars had the clear to go but fortunately didn't. 
As the light turns green for southbound traffic to enter the intersection the taxi can be seen swerving around a stopped grey hatchback. 
With the oncoming lane's light well-and-truly green it heads into the intersection, thankfully dashing through before cars or an oncoming cyclist had started into the intersection. 
Orsman, who has had a dashcam for two years, said this was the worst driving he had filmed, thanks to the swerve around the stopped car and heading into the intersection against a red light. 
He had not approached police with the footage - as he had with previous footage – as the licence plate of the car could not be clearly read. 
Kiwi Cabs general manager Muneer Oraha said the same driver had been warned about bad overtaking just a fortnight ago. This incident was the final straw and the driver would be called in to the office on Thursday. 
"I'm pretty sure he is done with company – he is fired." 
GPS technology meant the company was able to figure out which driver was behind the wheel. 
"It is affecting the image of the company, we do have a really good fleet," Oraha said. - Stuff
